awd_abstract_narration: This award is made as part of the FY 2017 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Daniel Le is "Aspects of the Langlands Correspondence modulo a Prime." The host institution for the fellowship is the University of Toronto, and the sponsoring scientist is Florian Herzig.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
Daniel Le has conducted research in algebraic number theory. A major theme in number theory concerns solutions to polynomial equations with integer coefficients. That such solutions are easy to verify but difficult to find makes number theory perfectly suited for cryptographic applications which are critical in modern communication.

The (classical) Langlands program, a major part of modern algebraic number theory, seeks to connect solutions to polynomial equations with integral coefficients to spectral properties of locally symmetric spaces. Spectral properties, for example, relate the sound of an instrument to its shape. A mod p and p-adic analogue of this program has developed over the last 30 years and played a key role in the resolution of many important conjectures in the classical Langlands program. The best-known application is Fermat's Last Theorem.

A major new theme in the area is a geometric enrichment of both sides of the Langlands program. A system of polynomial equations with integral coefficients can be repackaged in a rather elaborate way as a Galois representation. In collaborations, the PI has initiated a theory of local models for moduli of Galois representations, leading to significant progress in the mod p Langlands program. This theory and some applications have appeared in nine publications written by the PI and collaborators during the grant period.
